Name: backup
Description:
The "backup" command creates a new snapshot and saves the files and directories
given as the arguments.

Options.Name: dry-run
Options.Description: do not upload or write any data, just show what would be done

Options.Name: exclude
Options.Description: exclude a pattern (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: exclude-caches
Options.Description: excludes cache directories that are marked with a CACHEDIR.TAG file. See https://bford.info/cachedir/ for the Cache Directory Tagging Standard

Options.Name: exclude-file
Options.Description: read exclude patterns from a file (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: exclude-if-present
Options.Description: takes filename[:header], exclude contents of directories containing filename (except filename itself) if header of that file is as provided (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: exclude-larger-than
Options.Description: max size of the files to be backed up (allowed suffixes: k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T)

Options.Name: files-from
Options.Description: read the files to backup from file (can be combined with file args; can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: files-from-raw
Options.Description: read the files to backup from file (can be combined with file args; can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: files-from-verbatim
Options.Description: read the files to backup from file (can be combined with file args; can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: force
Options.Description: force re-reading the source files/directories (overrides the "parent" flag)

Options.Name: group-by
Options.Description: group snapshots by host, paths and/or tags, separated by comma (disable grouping with '')

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for backup

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: set the hostname for the snapshot manually (default: $RESTIC_HOST). To prevent an expensive rescan use the "parent" flag

Options.Name: iexclude
Options.Description: same as --exclude pattern but ignores the casing of filenames

Options.Name: iexclude-file
Options.Description: same as --exclude-file but ignores casing of filenames in patterns

Options.Name: ignore-ctime
Options.Description: ignore ctime changes when checking for modified files

Options.Name: ignore-inode
Options.Description: ignore inode number and ctime changes when checking for modified files

Options.Name: no-scan
Options.Description: do not run scanner to estimate size of backup

Options.Name: one-file-system
Options.Description: exclude other file systems, don't cross filesystem boundaries and subvolumes

Options.Name: parent
Options.Description: use this parent snapshot (default: latest snapshot in the group determined by --group-by and not newer than the timestamp determined by --time)

Options.Name: read-concurrency
Options.Description: read n files concurrently (default: $RESTIC_READ_CONCURRENCY or 2)

Options.Name: skip-if-unchanged
Options.Description: skip snapshot creation if identical to parent snapshot

Options.Name: stdin
Options.Description: read backup from stdin

Options.Name: stdin-filename
Options.Description: filename to use when reading from stdin

Options.Name: stdin-from-command
Options.Description: interpret arguments as command to execute and store its stdout

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: add tags for the new snapshot in the format tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: time
Options.Description: time of the backup (ex. '2012-11-01 22:08:41') (default: now)

Options.Name: with-atime
Options.Description: store the atime for all files and directories

Name: cache
Description: The "cache" command allows listing and cleaning local cache directories.

Options.Name: cleanup
Options.Description: remove old cache directories

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for cache

Options.Name: max-age
Options.Description: max age in days for cache directories to be considered old

Options.Name: no-size
Options.Description: do not output the size of the cache directories

Name: cat
Description: The "cat" command is used to print internal objects to stdout.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for cat

Name: check
Description:
The "check" command tests the repository for errors and reports any errors it
finds. It can also be used to read all data and therefore simulate a restore.

By default, the "check" command will always load all data directly from the
repository and not use a local cache.

Options.Name: check-unused
Options.Description: find unused blobs

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for check

Options.Name: read-data
Options.Description: read all data blobs

Options.Name: read-data-subset
Options.Description: read a subset of data packs, specified as 'n/t' for specific part, or either 'x%' or 'x.y%' or a size in bytes with suffixes k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T for a random subset

Options.Name: with-cache
Options.Description: use existing cache, only read uncached data from repository

Name: copy
Description:
The "copy" command copies one or more snapshots from one repository to another.

NOTE: This process will have to both download (read) and upload (write) the
entire snapshot(s) due to the different encryption keys used in the source and
destination repositories. This /may incur higher bandwidth usage and costs/ than
expected during normal backup runs.

NOTE: The copying process does not re-chunk files, which may break deduplication
between the files copied and files already stored in the destination repository.
This means that copied files, which existed in both the source and destination
repository, /may occupy up to twice their space/ in the destination repository.
This can be mitigated by the "--copy-chunker-params" option when initializing a
new destination repository using the "init" command.

Options.Name: from-insecure-no-password
Options.Description: use an empty password for the source repository, must be passed to every restic command (insecure)

Options.Name: from-key-hint
Options.Description: key ID of key to try decrypting the source repository first (default: $RESTIC_FROM_KEY_HINT)

Options.Name: from-password-command
Options.Description: shell command to obtain the source repository password from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_PASSWORD_COMMAND)

Options.Name: from-password-file
Options.Description: file to read the source repository password from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_PASSWORD_FILE)

Options.Name: from-repo
Options.Description: source repository to copy snapshots from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_REPOSITORY)

Options.Name: from-repository-file
Options.Description: file from which to read the source repository location to copy snapshots from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_REPOSITORY_FILE)

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for copy

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: key-hint2
Options.Description: key ID of key to try decrypting the destination repository first (default: $RESTIC_KEY_HINT2)

Options.Name: password-command2
Options.Description: shell command to obtain the destination repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_COMMAND2)

Options.Name: password-file2
Options.Description: file to read the destination repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_FILE2)

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: repo2
Options.Description: destination repository to copy snapshots to (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY2)

Options.Name: repository-file2
Options.Description: file from which to read the destination repository location to copy snapshots to (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY_FILE2)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Name: diff
Description:
The "diff" command shows differences from the first to the second snapshot. The
first characters in each line display what has happened to a particular file or
directory:

* `+` The item was added
* `-` The item was removed
* `U` The metadata (access mode, timestamps, ...) for the item was updated
* `M` The file's content was modified
* `T` The type was changed, e.g. a file was made a symlink
* `?` Bitrot detected: The file's content has changed but all metadata is the same


Metadata comparison will likely not work if a backup was created using the
'--ignore-inode' or '--ignore-ctime' option.

To only compare files in specific subfolders, you can use the
"snapshotID:subfolder" syntax, where "subfolder" is a path within the
snapshot.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for diff

Options.Name: metadata
Options.Description: print changes in metadata

Name: dump
Description:
The "dump" command extracts files from a snapshot from the repository. If a
single file is selected, it prints its contents to stdout. Folders are output
as a tar (default) or zip file containing the contents of the specified folder.
Pass "/" as file name to dump the whole snapshot as an archive file.

The special snapshotID "latest" can be used to use the latest snapshot in the
repository.

To include the folder content at the root of the archive, you can use the
"snapshotID:subfolder" syntax, where "subfolder" is a path within the
snapshot.

Options.Name: archive
Options.Description: set archive format as "tar" or "zip"

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for dump

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host, when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path, when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...], when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: target
Options.Description: write the output to target path

Name: find
Description:
The "find" command searches for files or directories in snapshots stored in the
repo.
It can also be used to search for restic blobs or trees for troubleshooting.

Options.Name: blob
Options.Description: pattern is a blob-ID

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for find

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: human-readable
Options.Description: print sizes in human readable format

Options.Name: ignore-case
Options.Description: ignore case for pattern

Options.Name: long
Options.Description: use a long listing format showing size and mode

Options.Name: newest
Options.Description: newest modification date/time

Options.Name: oldest
Options.Description: oldest modification date/time

Options.Name: pack
Options.Description: pattern is a pack-ID

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: show-pack-id
Options.Description: display the pack-ID the blobs belong to (with --blob or --tree)

Options.Name: snapshot
Options.Description: snapshot id to search in (can be given multiple times)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: tree
Options.Description: pattern is a tree-ID

Name: forget
Description:
The "forget" command removes snapshots according to a policy. All snapshots are
first divided into groups according to "--group-by", and after that the policy
specified by the "--keep-" options is applied to each group individually.
If there are not enough snapshots to keep one for each duration related
"--keep-{within-,}" option, the oldest snapshot in the group is kept
additionally.

Please note that this command really only deletes the snapshot object in the
repository, which is a reference to data stored there. In order to remove the
unreferenced data after "forget" was run successfully, see the "prune" command.

Please also read the documentation for "forget" to learn about some important
security considerations.

Options.Name: compact
Options.Description: use compact output format

Options.Name: dry-run
Options.Description: do not delete anything, just print what would be done

Options.Name: group-by
Options.Description: group snapshots by host, paths and/or tags, separated by comma (disable grouping with '')

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for forget

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: keep-daily
Options.Description: keep the last n daily snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all daily snapshots)

Options.Name: keep-hourly
Options.Description: keep the last n hourly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all hourly snapshots)

Options.Name: keep-last
Options.Description: keep the last n snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all snapshots)

Options.Name: keep-monthly
Options.Description: keep the last n monthly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all monthly snapshots)

Options.Name: keep-tag
Options.Description: keep snapshots with this taglist (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: keep-weekly
Options.Description: keep the last n weekly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all weekly snapshots)

Options.Name: keep-within
Options.Description: keep snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

Options.Name: keep-within-daily
Options.Description: keep daily snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

Options.Name: keep-within-hourly
Options.Description: keep hourly snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

Options.Name: keep-within-monthly
Options.Description: keep monthly snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

Options.Name: keep-within-weekly
Options.Description: keep weekly snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

Options.Name: keep-within-yearly
Options.Description: keep yearly snapshots that are newer than duration (eg. 1y5m7d2h) relative to the latest snapshot

Options.Name: keep-yearly
Options.Description: keep the last n yearly snapshots (use 'unlimited' to keep all yearly snapshots)

Options.Name: max-repack-size
Options.Description: maximum size to repack (allowed suffixes: k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T)

Options.Name: max-unused
Options.Description: tolerate given limit of unused data (absolute value in bytes with suffixes k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T, a value in % or the word 'unlimited')

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: prune
Options.Description: automatically run the 'prune' command if snapshots have been removed

Options.Name: repack-cacheable-only
Options.Description: only repack packs which are cacheable

Options.Name: repack-small
Options.Description: repack pack files below 80% of target pack size

Options.Name: repack-uncompressed
Options.Description: repack all uncompressed data

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: unsafe-allow-remove-all
Options.Description: allow deleting all snapshots of a snapshot group

Name: generate
Description:
The "generate" command writes automatically generated files (like the man pages
and the auto-completion files for bash, fish and zsh).

Options.Name: bash-completion
Options.Description: write bash completion file

Options.Name: fish-completion
Options.Description: write fish completion file

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for generate

Options.Name: man
Options.Description: write man pages to directory

Options.Name: powershell-completion
Options.Description: write powershell completion file

Options.Name: zsh-completion
Options.Description: write zsh completion file

Name: init
Description: The "init" command initializes a new repository.

Options.Name: copy-chunker-params
Options.Description: copy chunker parameters from the secondary repository (useful with the copy command)

Options.Name: from-insecure-no-password
Options.Description: use an empty password for the source repository, must be passed to every restic command (insecure)

Options.Name: from-key-hint
Options.Description: key ID of key to try decrypting the source repository first (default: $RESTIC_FROM_KEY_HINT)

Options.Name: from-password-command
Options.Description: shell command to obtain the source repository password from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_PASSWORD_COMMAND)

Options.Name: from-password-file
Options.Description: file to read the source repository password from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_PASSWORD_FILE)

Options.Name: from-repo
Options.Description: source repository to copy chunker parameters from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_REPOSITORY)

Options.Name: from-repository-file
Options.Description: file from which to read the source repository location to copy chunker parameters from (default: $RESTIC_FROM_REPOSITORY_FILE)

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for init

Options.Name: key-hint2
Options.Description: key ID of key to try decrypting the secondary repository first (default: $RESTIC_KEY_HINT2)

Options.Name: password-command2
Options.Description: shell command to obtain the secondary repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_COMMAND2)

Options.Name: password-file2
Options.Description: file to read the secondary repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_FILE2)

Options.Name: repo2
Options.Description: secondary repository to copy chunker parameters from (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY2)

Options.Name: repository-file2
Options.Description: file from which to read the secondary repository location to copy chunker parameters from (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY_FILE2)

Options.Name: repository-version
Options.Description: repository format version to use, allowed values are a format version, 'latest' and 'stable'

Name: key
Description:
The "key" command allows you to set multiple access keys or passwords
per repository.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for key

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: the hostname for new keys

Options.Name: new-password-file
Options.Description: file from which to read the new password

Options.Name: user
Options.Description: the username for new keys

Name: key-add
Description: The "add" sub-command creates a new key and validates the key. Returns the new key ID.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for add

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: the hostname for new key

Options.Name: new-insecure-no-password
Options.Description: add an empty password for the repository (insecure)

Options.Name: new-password-file
Options.Description: file from which to read the new password

Options.Name: user
Options.Description: the username for new key

Name: key-list
Description:
The "list" sub-command lists all the keys (passwords) associated with the repository.
Returns the key ID, username, hostname, created time and if it's the current key being
used to access the repository.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for list

Name: key-passwd
Description:
The "passwd" sub-command creates a new key, validates the key and remove the old key ID.
Returns the new key ID.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for passwd

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: the hostname for new key

Options.Name: new-insecure-no-password
Options.Description: add an empty password for the repository (insecure)

Options.Name: new-password-file
Options.Description: file from which to read the new password

Options.Name: user
Options.Description: the username for new key

Name: key-remove
Description:
The "remove" sub-command removes the selected key ID. The "remove" command does not allow
removing the current key being used to access the repository.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for remove

Name: list
Description: The "list" command allows listing objects in the repository based on type.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for list

Name: ls
Description:
The "ls" command lists files and directories in a snapshot.

The special snapshot ID "latest" can be used to list files and
directories of the latest snapshot in the repository. The
--host flag can be used in conjunction to select the latest
snapshot originating from a certain host only.

File listings can optionally be filtered by directories. Any
positional arguments after the snapshot ID are interpreted as
absolute directory paths, and only files inside those directories
will be listed. If the --recursive flag is used, then the filter
will allow traversing into matching directories' subfolders.
Any directory paths specified must be absolute (starting with
a path separator); paths use the forward slash '/' as separator.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for ls

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host, when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: human-readable
Options.Description: print sizes in human readable format

Options.Name: long
Options.Description: use a long listing format showing size and mode

Options.Name: ncdu
Options.Description: output NCDU export format (pipe into 'ncdu -f -')

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path, when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: recursive
Options.Description: include files in subfolders of the listed directories

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...], when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times)

Name: migrate
Description:
The "migrate" command checks which migrations can be applied for a repository
and prints a list with available migration names. If one or more migration
names are specified, these migrations are applied.

Options.Name: force
Options.Description: apply a migration a second time

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for migrate

Name: mount
Description:
The "mount" command mounts the repository via fuse to a directory. This is a
read-only mount.


If you need a different template for directories that contain snapshots,
you can pass a time template via --time-template and path templates via
--path-template.

Example time template without colons:


--time-template "2006-01-02_15-04-05"


You need to specify a sample format for exactly the following timestamp:


Mon Jan 2 15:04:05 -0700 MST 2006


For details please see the documentation for time.Format() at:
  https://godoc.org/time#Time.Format

For path templates, you can use the following patterns which will be replaced:
    %i by short snapshot ID
    %I by long snapshot ID
    %u by username
    %h by hostname
    %t by tags
    %T by timestamp as specified by --time-template

The default path templates are:
    "ids/%i"
    "snapshots/%T"
    "hosts/%h/%T"
    "tags/%t/%T"

Options.Name: allow-other
Options.Description: allow other users to access the data in the mounted directory

Options.Name: allow-root
Options.Description: allow root user to access the data in the mounted directory

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for mount

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: no-default-permissions
Options.Description: for 'allow-other', ignore Unix permissions and allow users to read all snapshot files

Options.Name: owner-root
Options.Description: use 'root' as the owner of files and dirs

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: path-template
Options.Description: set template for path names (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: snapshot-template
Options.Description: set template to use for snapshot dirs

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: time-template
Options.Description: set template to use for times

Name: prune
Description:
The "prune" command checks the repository and removes data that is not
referenced and therefore not needed any more.

Options.Name: dry-run
Options.Description: do not modify the repository, just print what would be done

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for prune

Options.Name: max-repack-size
Options.Description: maximum size to repack (allowed suffixes: k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T)

Options.Name: max-unused
Options.Description: tolerate given limit of unused data (absolute value in bytes with suffixes k/K, m/M, g/G, t/T, a value in % or the word 'unlimited')

Options.Name: repack-cacheable-only
Options.Description: only repack packs which are cacheable

Options.Name: repack-small
Options.Description: repack pack files below 80% of target pack size

Options.Name: repack-uncompressed
Options.Description: repack all uncompressed data

Options.Name: unsafe-recover-no-free-space
Options.Description: UNSAFE, READ THE DOCUMENTATION BEFORE USING! Try to recover a repository stuck with no free space. Do not use without trying out 'prune --max-repack-size 0' first.

Name: rebuild-index
Description:
The "rebuild-index" command creates a new index based on the pack files in the
repository.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for rebuild-index

Options.Name: read-all-packs
Options.Description: read all pack files to generate new index from scratch

Name: recover
Description:
The "recover" command builds a new snapshot from all directories it can find in
the raw data of the repository which are not referenced in an existing snapshot.
It can be used if, for example, a snapshot has been removed by accident with "forget".

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for recover

Name: repair
Description: Repair the repository

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for repair

Name: repair-index
Description:
The "repair index" command creates a new index based on the pack files in the
repository.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for index

Options.Name: read-all-packs
Options.Description: read all pack files to generate new index from scratch

Name: repair-packs
Description:
WARNING: The CLI for this command is experimental and will likely change in the future!

The "repair packs" command extracts intact blobs from the specified pack files, rebuilds
the index to remove the damaged pack files and removes the pack files from the repository.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for packs

Name: repair-snapshots
Description:
The "repair snapshots" command repairs broken snapshots. It scans the given
snapshots and generates new ones with damaged directories and file contents
removed. If the broken snapshots are deleted, a prune run will be able to
clean up the repository.

The command depends on a correct index, thus make sure to run "repair index"
first!

Options.Name: dry-run
Options.Description: do not do anything, just print what would be done

Options.Name: forget
Options.Description: remove original snapshots after creating new ones

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for snapshots

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Name: restore
Description:
The "restore" command extracts the data from a snapshot from the repository to
a directory.

The special snapshotID "latest" can be used to restore the latest snapshot in the
repository.

To only restore a specific subfolder, you can use the "snapshotID:subfolder"
syntax, where "subfolder" is a path within the snapshot.

Options.Name: delete
Options.Description: delete files from target directory if they do not exist in snapshot. Use '--dry-run -vv' to check what would be deleted

Options.Name: dry-run
Options.Description: do not write any data, just show what would be done

Options.Name: exclude
Options.Description: exclude a pattern (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: exclude-file
Options.Description: read exclude patterns from a file (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for restore

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host, when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: iexclude
Options.Description: same as --exclude pattern but ignores the casing of filenames

Options.Name: iexclude-file
Options.Description: same as --exclude-file but ignores casing of filenames in patterns

Options.Name: iinclude
Options.Description: same as --include pattern but ignores the casing of filenames

Options.Name: iinclude-file
Options.Description: same as --include-file but ignores casing of filenames in patterns

Options.Name: include
Options.Description: include a pattern (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: include-file
Options.Description: read include patterns from a file (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: overwrite
Options.Description: overwrite behavior, one of (always|if-changed|if-newer|never) (default: always)

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path, when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: sparse
Options.Description: restore files as sparse

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...], when snapshot ID "latest" is given (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: target
Options.Description: directory to extract data to

Options.Name: verify
Options.Description: verify restored files content

Name: rewrite
Description:
The "rewrite" command excludes files from existing snapshots. It creates new
snapshots containing the same data as the original ones, but without the files
you specify to exclude. All metadata (time, host, tags) will be preserved.

The snapshots to rewrite are specified using the --host, --tag and --path options,
or by providing a list of snapshot IDs. Please note that specifying neither any of
these options nor a snapshot ID will cause the command to rewrite all snapshots.

The special tag 'rewrite' will be added to the new snapshots to distinguish
them from the original ones, unless --forget is used. If the --forget option is
used, the original snapshots will instead be directly removed from the repository.

Please note that the --forget option only removes the snapshots and not the actual
data stored in the repository. In order to delete the no longer referenced data,
use the "prune" command.

Options.Name: dry-run
Options.Description: do not do anything, just print what would be done

Options.Name: exclude
Options.Description: exclude a pattern (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: exclude-file
Options.Description: read exclude patterns from a file (can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: forget
Options.Description: remove original snapshots after creating new ones

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for rewrite

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: iexclude
Options.Description: same as --exclude pattern but ignores the casing of filenames

Options.Name: iexclude-file
Options.Description: same as --exclude-file but ignores casing of filenames in patterns

Options.Name: new-host
Options.Description: replace hostname

Options.Name: new-time
Options.Description: replace time of the backup

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Name: self-update
Description:
The command "self-update" downloads the latest stable release of restic from
GitHub and replaces the currently running binary. After download, the
authenticity of the binary is verified using the GPG signature on the release
files.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for self-update

Options.Name: output
Options.Description: Save the downloaded file as filename (default: running binary itself)

Name: snapshots
Description: The "snapshots" command lists all snapshots stored in the repository.

Options.Name: compact
Options.Description: use compact output format

Options.Name: group-by
Options.Description: group snapshots by host, paths and/or tags, separated by comma

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for snapshots

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: last
Options.Description: only show the last snapshot for each host and path

Options.Name: latest
Options.Description: only show the last n snapshots for each host and path

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Name: stats
Description:
The "stats" command walks one or multiple snapshots in a repository
and accumulates statistics about the data stored therein. It reports
on the number of unique files and their sizes, according to one of
the counting modes as given by the --mode flag.

It operates on all snapshots matching the selection criteria or all
snapshots if nothing is specified. The special snapshot ID "latest"
is also supported. Some modes make more sense over
just a single snapshot, while others are useful across all snapshots,
depending on what you are trying to calculate.

The modes are:

* restore-size: (default) Counts the size of the restored files.
* files-by-contents: Counts total size of unique files, where a file is
considered unique if it has unique contents.
* raw-data: Counts the size of blobs in the repository, regardless of
how many files reference them.
* blobs-per-file: A combination of files-by-contents and raw-data.


Refer to the online manual for more details about each mode.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for stats

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: mode
Options.Description: counting mode: restore-size (default), files-by-contents, blobs-per-file or raw-data

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Name: tag
Description:
The "tag" command allows you to modify tags on exiting snapshots.

You can either set/replace the entire set of tags on a snapshot, or
add tags to/remove tags from the existing set.

When no snapshot-ID is given, all snapshots matching the host, tag and path filter criteria are modified.

Options.Name: add
Options.Description: tags which will be added to the existing tags in the format tag[,tag,...] (can be given multiple times)

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for tag

Options.Name: host
Options.Description: only consider snapshots for this host (can be specified multiple times) (default: $RESTIC_HOST)

Options.Name: path
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including this (absolute) path (can be specified multiple times, snapshots must include all specified paths)

Options.Name: remove
Options.Description: tags which will be removed from the existing tags in the format tag[,tag,...] (can be given multiple times)

Options.Name: set
Options.Description: tags which will replace the existing tags in the format tag[,tag,...] (can be given multiple times)

Options.Name: tag
Options.Description: only consider snapshots including tag[,tag,...] (can be specified multiple times)

Name: unlock
Description: The "unlock" command removes stale locks that have been created by other restic processes.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for unlock

Options.Name: remove-all
Options.Description: remove all locks, even non-stale ones

Name: version
Description:
The "version" command prints detailed information about the build environment
and the version of this software.

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for version

Name: __default
Description:
restic is a backup program which allows saving multiple revisions of files and
directories in an encrypted repository stored on different backends.

The full documentation can be found at https://restic.readthedocs.io/ .

Options.Name: cacert
Options.Description: file to load root certificates from (default: use system certificates or $RESTIC_CACERT)

Options.Name: cache-dir
Options.Description: set the cache directory. (default: use system default cache directory)

Options.Name: cleanup-cache
Options.Description: auto remove old cache directories

Options.Name: compression
Options.Description: compression mode (only available for repository format version 2), one of (auto|off|max) (default: $RESTIC_COMPRESSION)

Options.Name: help
Options.Description: help for restic

Options.Name: http-user-agent
Options.Description: set a http user agent for outgoing http requests

Options.Name: insecure-no-password
Options.Description: use an empty password for the repository, must be passed to every restic command (insecure)

Options.Name: insecure-tls
Options.Description: skip TLS certificate verification when connecting to the repository (insecure)

Options.Name: json
Options.Description: set output mode to JSON for commands that support it

Options.Name: key-hint
Options.Description: key ID of key to try decrypting first (default: $RESTIC_KEY_HINT)

Options.Name: limit-download
Options.Description: limits downloads to a maximum rate in KiB/s. (default: unlimited)

Options.Name: limit-upload
Options.Description: limits uploads to a maximum rate in KiB/s. (default: unlimited)

Options.Name: no-cache
Options.Description: do not use a local cache

Options.Name: no-extra-verify
Options.Description: skip additional verification of data before upload (see documentation)

Options.Name: no-lock
Options.Description: do not lock the repository, this allows some operations on read-only repositories

Options.Name: option
Options.Description: set extended option (key=value, can be specified multiple times)

Options.Name: pack-size
Options.Description: set target pack size in MiB, created pack files may be larger (default: $RESTIC_PACK_SIZE)

Options.Name: password-command
Options.Description: shell command to obtain the repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_COMMAND)

Options.Name: password-file
Options.Description: file to read the repository password from (default: $RESTIC_PASSWORD_FILE)

Options.Name: quiet
Options.Description: do not output comprehensive progress report

Options.Name: repo
Options.Description: repository to backup to or restore from (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY)

Options.Name: repository-file
Options.Description: file to read the repository location from (default: $RESTIC_REPOSITORY_FILE)

Options.Name: retry-lock
Options.Description: retry to lock the repository if it is already locked, takes a value like 5m or 2h (default: no retries)

Options.Name: tls-client-cert
Options.Description: path to a file containing PEM encoded TLS client certificate and private key (default: $RESTIC_TLS_CLIENT_CERT)

Options.Name: verbose
Options.Description: be verbose (specify multiple times or a level using --verbose=n, max level/times is 2)
